My husband and sister and I, are traveling to Europe next week. We start in Ireland, but will fly to Florence and plan on driving down and through Italy to Rome for a cruise. comments.comment_text: If you don’t want to drive it’s super easy to take the train to different cities!

According to the many posts I've read, driving in Italy is not recommended for tourists. Issues with parking, or not being able to drive at all in some cities. If you do, you'll need to know enough Italian to read road signs, have an international driver's license and be able to drive a stick shift.
The train system in Italy is wonderful and easy. If you want to get to places that aren't accessible by rail, hire a driver. The front desk at your hotel can help with that.

We drove several times. Apple Maps is better than google as it alerts you to speed cameras. Pay attention to the ZTLs and their operating times. Make sure you have cash ready on the toll roads as sometimes you get a ticket and pay at the exit and sometimes you just pay at the toll. The sign with the ticket in the hand means that there is an attendant, if there is no hand it’s just a machine and often difficult. We much prefer the attendant. Some rental cars allow you to go thru the reader and send a bill but there are fees involved. If you drive a stick the rental will be cheaper. Many cars are diesel. Ask before you leave what gas. Ours had some mystery blue cap next to the diesel that confused even the gas attendants. Turns out it’s some fuel additive you must buy inside a store. Have offline maps as a backup if you lose cell service. (Screenshot the steps when you do have good service). Each car had a different size charger plug. The new Audi we rented only had usbc chargers and the flat magnetic charger that overheated our phones. We loved driving and stopping to see things. Here is a possible itinerary for your 15-20 day trip to Italy, starting in Florence and ending in Rome:

* Day 1: Arrive in Florence and check into your hotel. Spend the afternoon exploring the city center, including the Piazza del Duomo, the Uffizi Gallery, and the Ponte Vecchio.

[Image of Florence Uffizi Gallery]
[Image of Florence Ponte Vecchio]
* Day 2: Take a day trip to Siena, a beautiful medieval town in Tuscany. Climb the steps to the top of the Piazza del Campo for stunning views of the city.
[Image of Siena Piazza del Campo]
* Day 3: Drive to the Cinque Terre, a group of five villages perched on the cliffs along the Italian Riviera. Hike between the villages, go swimming in the Mediterranean Sea, and enjoy the stunning views.
[Image of Cinque Terre villages]
[Image of Cinque Terre hiking]
[Image of Cinque Terre swimming]
* Day 4: Drive to Pisa, home of the Leaning Tower. Spend a few hours exploring the city and climbing the tower.
[Image of Pisa Leaning Tower]
* Day 5+: Drive to Lake Como, a beautiful lake in northern Italy. Spend a few days relaxing by the lake, swimming, and hiking in the mountains.
[Image of Lake Como Italy]. Varenna, Bellagio are fun places to see here.
* Day 6: Drive to Verona, a city in northeastern Italy famous for its Roman amphitheater and Juliet's balcony.
[Image of Verona amphitheater]
[Image of Verona Juliet's balcony]
* Day 7: Drive to Venice, a city built on canals. Take a gondola ride, explore the Piazza San Marco, and get lost in the maze of narrow streets.
[Image of Venice gondola ride]
[Image of Venice Piazza San Marco]
[Image of Venice narrow streets]
* Day 8: Take a day trip to the Dolomites, a mountain range in northeastern Italy. Go hiking, biking, or skiing in the mountains.
[Image of Dolomites mountains]
* Day 9: Drive to Rome, the capital of Italy. Spend a few days exploring the city's ancient ruins, including the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Pantheon.
[Image of Rome Colosseum]
[Image of Rome Roman Forum]
[Image of Rome Pantheon]
* Day 10: Take a cooking class in Rome and learn how to make traditional Italian dishes.
* Day 11: Enjoy a leisurely breakfast at your hotel before boarding your cruise.

This is just a suggestion, of course, and you can adjust the itinerary to fit your interests and time constraints. If you are nervous about driving in Italy, you can always take trains or buses between destinations. However, driving will give you the most flexibility and allow you to see more of the country.

Here are some tips for driving in Italy:

* Be prepared for narrow roads and hairpin turns.
* Drive slowly and obey the speed limit.
* Be aware of pedestrians and cyclists.
* Use your turn signals and don't be afraid to honk your horn.
* If you get lost, ask for directions at a gas station or tourist information office.

Here are some tips for booking train travel in Italy:

* Start by planning your itinerary and figuring out which cities you want to visit. Once you know where you're going, you can start looking at train schedules and prices.
* There are a few different train companies that operate in Italy, so it's important to compare prices before you book. I recommend using a website like Trainline to compare prices from different companies.
* If you're traveling during the peak season (April-June and September-Octob
er), it's a good idea to book your train tickets in advance. This will ensure that you get the best prices and that you don't miss out on a train.
* When you book your tickets, make sure to pay attention to the class of service you want. There are three classes of service on Italian trains: economy, premium, and business. Economy class is the cheapest, but it can be crowded and noisy. Premium class is a bit more expensive, but it offers more legroom and a quieter ride. Business class is the most expensive, but it offers the best amenities, such as free Wi-Fi and access to a lounge.
* Once you have your tickets, make sure to print them out or save them on your phone. You will need to show your tickets to the conductor when you board the train.

Transfers are just the connections between trains. For example, if you're taking a train from Rome to Florence, you might have to transfer trains in Bologna. The travel agent is probably warning you about transfers because they can be confusing if you're not familiar with the Italian train system. However, they're not really that difficult to figure out. Just make sure to pay attention to the signs and ask for help if you need it.

I think Cinque Terre is a great place to visit, and I don't think the travel agent is wrong about the transportation being difficult. The five villages that make up Cinque Terre are all very small and they're only accessible by foot, train, or boat. The trains are the most efficient way to get around, but they can be crowded and slow. If you're not used to walking, you might find it difficult to get around Cinque Terre.

However, I think the difficulty of transportation is part of what makes Cinque Terre so special. It's a very unique place and it's worth the effort to get there. If you're willing to put in a little bit of effort, you'll be rewarded with some amazing views and some truly unforgettable experiences.

Here are some tips for getting around Cinque Terre:

* The Cinque Terre Card is a great way to save money on transportation in Cinque Terre. The card gives you unlimited access to the trains, buses, and boats that serve the five villages.
* If you're not up for a lot of walking, you can take the Cinque Terre Express Bus. The bus stops at all five villages and it's a great way to see the coast without having to walk.
* If you're traveling with a group, you can rent a boat. This is a great way to explore the coast at your own pace and to get some amazing views.

I hope this helps!
